name: Eurasian Siskin
description: A tiny bird with a conical beak and overall gray-green and yellow plumage. The male is more vividly yellow than the female and has a black crown.
spread_note: Resident year-round in Central Europe, where northern siskins migrate for winter. Breeds in Northern Europe and Eastern Asia. Partially migratory, Central and Northern European birds winter in Southern Europe and North Africa, Eastern Asian ones in South Asia.
food_note: Primarily seed-eating; during nesting, it also hunts insects, mainly beetles.
proportions: Length 11–12.5 cm; wingspan 20–23 cm; weight 9–14 g
reproduction: Females lay 2–6 eggs, incubating them alone for 12–14 days.
attractions: The Eurasian siskin is a lively, active bird, most noticeable outside the breeding season when it’s less discreet. From autumn to spring, it often forms small flocks, climbing nimbly in tree crowns, sometimes hanging upside down to peck seeds. Its nest is deeply cup-shaped and well-camouflaged high in trees. Formerly kept as cage birds, siskins are undemanding and adapt easily to human presence.
